{p}(x)}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>ψ</mi><mi>p</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mi>d</mi><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mi>p</mi></msub></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msubsup><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mi>p</mi><mo>′</mo></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mi>p</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

The function $\psi_p$ has the following properties (see~\cite[p.~374, Lemma~5]{MC-Krashiqi-Mansour-Shabani} and \cite[p.~29, Lemma~2.3]{VA}).
\begin{enumerate}
\item
It has the following representations
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E7.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\psi_{p}(x)=\ln p-\sum_{k=0}^{p}\frac{1}{x+k}=\ln p-\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{1-e%
^{-(p+1)t}}{1-e^{-t}}e^{-xt}dt." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>ψ</mi><mi>p</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>p</mi></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mi>p</mi></munderover><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>p</mi></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mn>0</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></msubsup><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:

For the history, backgrounds, applications and alternative proofs of this conclusion, please refer to~\cite{theta-new-proof.tex-BKMS}, \cite[p.~8, Section~1.6.6]{bounds-two-gammas.tex} and closely-related references therein.
\par


A positive function $f$ is said to be {\em logarithmically completely monotonic} \cite{MC-Krashiqi-Mansour-Shabani}  on an open interval $I$, if $f$ satisfies
prevtext:
\item
It is increasing on $(0,\infty)$ and $\psi'_p$ is completely monotonic on $(0,\infty)$.
\end{enumerate}

\par
In~\cite[pp.~374\nobreakdash--375, Theorem~1]{psi-alzer}, it was proved that the function

is completely monotonic on $(0,\infty)$ if and only if $\alpha\le1$.

For the history, backgrounds, applications and alternative proofs of this conclusion, please refer to~\cite{theta-new-proof.tex-BKMS}, \cite[p.~8, Section~1.6.6]{bounds-two-gammas.tex} and closely-related references therein.
\par


A positive function $f$ is said to be {\em logarithmically completely monotonic} \cite{MC-Krashiqi-Mansour-Shabani}  on an open interval $I$, if $f$ satisfies
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E9.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="(-1)^{n}[\ln f(x)]^{(n)}\geq 0,(x\in I,n=1,2,\ldots)." display="block"><mrow><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mi>n</mi></msup><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>ln</mi><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msup><mo>≥</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>I</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E10.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="q(t):=t^{t(\psi(t)-\log t)-\gamma}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>q</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>:=</mo><msup><mi>t</mi><mrow><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>ψ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>γ</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E11.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="q(t):=t^{t(\psi(t)-\log t)-\gamma}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>q</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>:=</mo><msup><mi>t</mi><mrow><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>ψ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>γ</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></math>

nexttext:
Let $\displaystyle h(t)=-\gamma \cdot\log t, g(t)=-\log t; f(t)=t\cdot(\log t-\psi(t))$.
Alzer \cite{psi-alzer} proved that the function $f(t)=t\cdot(\log t-\psi(t))$ is strictly completely monotonic on $(0,\infty)$. The functions $g(t)=-\log t$ and $h(t)=-\gamma \cdot\log t$ are also strictly completely monotonic on $(0,1)$. We complete the proof by recalling the results from \cite{widder}.

1) The product of two completely monotone functions is completely monotonic function.

2) A non-negative finite linear combination of completely monotone functions
is completely monotonic function.
\end{proof}

We extend the previous result to the following theorem.
\begin{theorem}
The function
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E12.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\log q(t)=-t\cdot(\log t-\psi(t))\log t-\gamma\cdot\log t" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>q</mi></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>ψ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>γ</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mrow><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

prevtext:
Let $\displaystyle h(t)=-\gamma \cdot\log t, g(t)=-\log t; f(t)=t\cdot(\log t-\psi(t))$.
Alzer \cite{psi-alzer} proved that the function $f(t)=t\cdot(\log t-\psi(t))$ is strictly completely monotonic on $(0,\infty)$. The functions $g(t)=-\log t$ and $h(t)=-\gamma \cdot\log t$ are also strictly completely monotonic on $(0,1)$. We complete the proof by recalling the results from \cite{widder}.

1) The product of two completely monotone functions is completely monotonic function.

2) A non-negative finite linear combination of completely monotone functions
is completely monotonic function.
\end{proof}

We extend the previous result to the following theorem.
\begin{theorem}
The function
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E13.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="q_{p}(t):=t^{t\cdot\big{(}\psi_{p}(t)-\log\frac{pt}{t+p+1}\big{)}-\gamma}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>q</mi><mi>p</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>:=</mo><msup><mi>t</mi><mrow><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mrow><mo maxsize="171%" minsize="171%">(</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>ψ</mi><mi>p</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>p</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow><mo maxsize="171%" minsize="171%">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>γ</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E14.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\log q_{p}(t)=-t\big{(}\log\frac{pt}{t+p+1}-\psi(t)\big{)}\log t-\gamma\cdot\log
t" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><msub><mi>q</mi><mi>p</mi></msub></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo maxsize="120%" minsize="120%">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>p</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>ψ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo maxsize="120%" minsize="120%">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>γ</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mrow><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E15.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle q(t):=t^{t\cdot(\psi_{q}(t)-\log\theta(t))-\gamma}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>q</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>:=</mo><msup><mi>t</mi><mrow><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>ψ</mi><mi>q</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>γ</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></math>
